title: World War Two bomb scare sees thousands evacuated from Italian city
text:
Italian authorities defuse a World War II bomb found in a construction site in Piazza Verdi (Picture: Italian Army)

Italian authorities were forced to evacuate 4,000 people from a busy city centre today so they could defuse a Second World War bomb.

The device was found in Piazza Verdi, in the northern city of Bolzano, during construction work and was made safe during a three-hour operation.

Residents were ushered out of their homes before an alarm signalled the all-clear to reopen the city centre.

A nearby main road and a railway line connecting Italy with Austria and Germany also had to be shut down due to the bomb, but both have since reopened.

Pictures showed bomb disposal specialists putting the device on a wooden crate before it was winched out and defused.

Specialists defuse the World War II bomb (Picture: Italian Army)

A deserted road in the northern Italian city of Bolzano (Picture: ANSA)

The device was winched out of the construction site (Picture: Italian Army)

Thousands had to be evacuated while the bomb was made safe (Picture: Italian Army)

Reports suggested it took three hours to defuse the bomb (Picture: Italian Army)

The ‘aerial bomb’ was winched to safety (Picture: Italian Army)

Media outlet Neue Suedtiroler Tageszeitung identified the equipment as an aerial bomb.

Bolzano, which sits in the northern Alto-Adige region bordering Austria, suffered 13 major bombing raids that damaged 60 per cent of the city during the war.

Historian Ettore Frangipane states that 200 people were killed.

The region was part of a broad swathe of northern Italy that remained under Nazi-occupation long after Italy’s 1943 Allied surrender.

description: Aerial bomb found in northern Italian city of Bolzano defused after three hours, following evacuation of residents.
